title: [K-12] Blended Learning Environment Design in Business Administration: Flipped Learning-Based Socioeconomic Decision-Making Competency Enhancement Strategies

context.prior_knowledge: Understanding of foundational business theories and basic instructional design principles, basic comprehension of social science inquiry methods (problem recognition-hypothesis formulation-data collection-analysis-conclusion drawing), fundamental awareness of social institutions (market economy, government regulation) and cultural diversity
context.additional_context: Practical instructional design course for pre-service/in-service teachers, emphasizing educational design skills reflecting socio-economic contexts (global economy, community issues, cultural diversity) in business/economics fields. Highlights civic economic decision-making and social impact assessment competencies

learning_goals: When applying a flipped learning-based blended model to business education, at least three design frameworks reflecting social science concepts—such as market structure, corporate relationships, and resource allocation—should be proposed, considering interactions among economic agents and social responsibility elements.

Learners can link online pre-learning materials (videos, quizzes) with offline activities (discussions, projects) to create three specific social studies lesson plans within two weeks. These plans must meet at least four of the five peer-reviewed and teacher-feedback criteria: creativity, collaboration, practicality, systematic structure, and social impact. Case analyses reflecting economic, political, and cultural contexts are included.

At least two formative assessments can be designed to encourage learner engagement through interactive activities (e.g., role-play, simulated investment games), incorporating elements such as analysis of relationships among economic agents and social responsibility (e.g., ethical decision-making, sustainability).
difficulty: Easy - Simple structure with minimal constraints
